heisig_chinese_memo: Since onions are the flower which is closest to your heart, you use your gps to find those farmer's market locations to get the best ones.
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: The onion is a plant that has such spicy fumes, that you have to cry as if your heart is in a double knot so you hurriedly chop them up to get it over with.
humanum_full_description_en:
From the sound of "艸", "悤", the original meaning is a perennial herb with cylindrical leaves, hollow in the middle, cylindrical bulbs, and small white flowers. "Shuowen": "Cai Ye. From the 艸, palpitate." "Book of Rites-Nei Ze": "Chun, spring onion, autumn mustard."

" Green onion " can mean wild onions growing in the mountains. "Shanhai Jing‧ Beishan Jing": "Mountains in Bianchun are full of green onions, sunflowers, leeks, peaches, and plums." Guo Pu's note: "Mountain green onions, named 茖, big leaves.

" Green onion " can also mean turquoise. "Poetry‧Xiaoya‧Caifu": "Emperor Zhu Fusi, there are green onions." Mao Chuan: "Green onions, Cang Ye."

" Green onions " can also be compared to women's slender fingers. Tang Yuanzhen "Chun": "Open the teeth and prepare shellfish, stretch the silk and cut the green onions."
humanum_short_description_en: From the sound of "艸", "悤", the original meaning is a perennial herb with cylindrical leaves, hollow in the middle, cylindrical bulbs, and small white flowers.
humanum_full_description:
從「艸」，「悤」聲，本義為多年生草本植物，葉子圓筒形，中間空，鱗莖圓柱形，開小白花。《說文》：「菜也。从艸，悤聲。」 《禮記‧內則》：「膾，春用蔥，秋用芥。」

　　「蔥」可表示山中生長的野蔥。《山海經‧北山經》：「邊春之山，多蔥、葵、韭、桃、李。」郭璞注：「山蔥，名茖，大葉。」

　　「蔥」也可表示青綠色。《詩‧小雅‧采芑》：「朱芾斯皇，有瑲蔥珩。」毛傳：「蔥，蒼也。」

　　「蔥」還可比喻婦女纖細的手指。唐元稹〈春〉：「啟齒呈編貝，彈絲動削蔥。」
humanum_short_description: 從「艸」，「悤」聲，本義為多年生草本植物，葉子圓筒形，中間空，鱗莖圓柱形，開小白花。

Freq: 8142
Chinese: Since onions are the flower which is closest to your heart, you use your gps to find those farmer's market locations to get the best ones.
Meaning: onion
Hanzi: 葱
Story: The onion is a plant that has such spicy fumes, that you have to cry as if your heart is in a double knot so you hurriedly chop them up to get it over with.
Kind: traditional
從「 艸 」，「 悤 」聲，本義為多年生草本植物，葉子圓筒形，中間空，鱗莖圓柱形，開小白花。《說文》：「菜也。从艸，悤聲。」 《禮記‧內則》：「膾，春用蔥，秋用芥。」 「 蔥 」可表示山中生長的野蔥。《山海經‧北山經》：「邊春之山，多蔥、葵、韭、桃、李。」郭璞注：「山蔥，名茖，大葉。」 「 蔥 」也可表示青綠色。《詩‧小雅‧采芑》：「朱芾斯皇，有瑲蔥珩。」毛傳：「蔥，蒼也。」 「 蔥 」還可比喻婦女纖細的手指。唐元稹〈春〉：「啟齒呈編貝，彈絲動削蔥。」
From the sound of " 艸", " 悤", the original meaning is a perennial herb with cylindrical leaves, hollow in the middle, cylindrical bulbs, and small white flowers. "Shuowen": "Cai Ye. From the 艸, palpitate." "Book of Rites-Nei Ze": "Chun, spring onion, autumn mustard." " Green onion" can mean wild onions growing in the mountains. "Shanhai Jing‧ Beishan Jing": "Mountains in Bianchun are full of green onions, sunflowers, leeks, peaches, and plums." Guo Pu's note: "Mountain green onions, named 茖, big leaves. " Green onion" can also mean turquoise. "Poetry‧Xiaoya‧Caifu": "Emperor Zhu Fusi, there are green onions." Mao Chuan: "Green onions, Cang Ye." " Green onions" can also be compared to women's slender fingers. Tang Yuanzhen "Chun": "Open the teeth and prepare shellfish, stretch the silk and cut the green onions."

蔥字的基本解释

蔥
cōng
同“葱”。

蔥字的汉语字典释义

[①]［cōng］
［《廣韻》倉紅切，平東，清。］
亦作“茐1”。亦作“蔥1”。亦作“1”。
(1)多年生草本植物。叶子圆筒形，中间空，鳞茎圆柱形，开小白花。种类很多，有大葱、香葱等。可作蔬菜或调味品，亦可作药用。
(2)指山中生长的野葱。
(3)青绿色。
(4)古剑名。
(5)旧时比喻妇女纤细的手指。
[②]［chuāng］
［《集韻》初江切，平江，初。］
通“窗1”。
见“葱2靈”。

蔥字的康熙字典解释

【申集上】【艸字部】　蔥； 康熙笔画：17； 页码：页1055第11
【集韻】葱古作蔥。註詳九畫。

蔥字的源字形

字源演变：

小篆楷体

字形对比：

中国大陆宋体台湾细明体香港明体日本明朝体韩国明朝体旧字形
蔥字的起名意思

暂无。

shallot
cōng
Same as "onion".
shallot
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[①]［cōng］
["Guangyun" Canghongqie, Pingdong, Qing. ]
Also known as "茐1". Also known as "onion 1". Also known as "1".
(1) Perennial herb. The leaves are cylindrical, hollow in the middle, and cylindrical bulbs with small white flowers. There are many types, such as green onions and chives. It can be used as a vegetable or condiment, and it can also be used as medicine.
(2) Refers to wild onions growing in the mountains.
(3) Turquoise.
(4) Ancient sword name.
(5) The old metaphor for women's slender fingers.
[②]［chuāng］
["Ji Yun" Chu Jiang Qi, Ping Jiang, Chu. ]
Open "Window 1".
See "Cong 2 Ling".
